newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.African bourse prepares for cut-throat future.
newsitem.headline: S.African bourse prepares for cut-throat future.

text.p: South Africa's stock market aims to boost efficiency and become more transparent in order to survive in the increasingly cut-throat global marketplace, exchange president Russell Loubser told Reuters on Wednesday.
With exchange controls and tariff barriers tumbling around the world, all forms of capital are becoming more mobile. So are the traders that deal in it.
Loubser said the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE), virtually isolated during the apartheid era, now had to compete for business internationally.

"We are moving to a culture where we are going to remove all exchange controls. Traders will come and trade where the market is most efficient and where the transparency is the best," Loubser said in an interview.
Loubser said isolation could no longer be used as an excuse for some of the anachronisms of the JSE -- which celebrates its 110th birthday later this year.
The JSE, which dwarfs any other stock market in Africa, has scrapped its old trading floor and imported a hi-tech electronic dealing system called JET.
JET has ironed out most of its early technical problems and is now up and running. "It has still got faults, but they will be corrected over time," he said.

Having banished paper slips from dealing the JSE also aims to computerise its less front-line operations by working with banks to set up an electronic scrip registry. This would automatically register changes in share-ownership without the need for physically shifting masses of certificates around.
"First we must stop the paper being mobile. Therefore we must get those scrip papers filed centrally and keep them there," Loubser said.
The certificates could then be replaced with an electronic registry, which could be in place in 1998.

Loubser, who replaced former JSE President Roy Andersen at the start of this month, said greater co-operation was needed between the JSE and South Africa's two other licensed exchanges -- the South African Futures Exchange and the Bond Exchange.
This would allow cross surveillance of the three markets and allow players with offsetting positions in more than one exchange to calculate net risks and net margins.
"The technology is there. A lot of negotiations are needed between the JSE and the other markets," he said.

One dark cloud on the JSE's horizon is South Africa's unwanted reputation for insider trading. One recent case that caused a stir followed the apparent leaking of news of a big shake-up at car firm Automakers Ltd earlier this month.
The firm's shares shot up ahead of news that majority shareholder Sankorp would make a payout to minorities at a substantial premium to the prevailing market price.

Loubser said South African law, which still only deals with the equities market, makes insider trading a criminal rather than civil offence. This places a higher burden of proof on an area of crime that is already notoriously difficult to trace.
However, a government-appointed committee into the issue is set to announce its recommendations in the next few weeks and is expected to suggest the law be changed.
The JSE also plans to install by April the Stock Exchange News Service which will rapidly transmit price-sensitive information to clients in a way similar to that used on the London Stock Exchange.

This will replace the current archaic mixture of company's conveying news by faxed press releases or placing adverts in local newspapers -- with all the attendant delays. "It is not just changing the legislation to catch insider trading, it is about removing the ability in the first place," Loubser said.
